unPrism: Simple Secure Comms at Home

As the LEAP project says, democracy of all shapes and sizes is meaningless without the right to whisper. All democracies currently comprise groups of widely divergent levels of resource and power (think Rupert Murdoch or Bill Gates vs. a homeless person, or a million other less extreme examples). It is impossible, in these circumstances, to remove the ability of the powerful to coerce the powerless. As a consequence, if the powerful have universal access to communication, democracy is broken.

Now consider Edward Snowden's revelations about Prism, Tempora and related programmes. It turns our that all your email is bcc'd to BoredYoungSpies@nsa.gov, and that you're a Facebook friend of NoSenseOfHumour@gchq.gov.uk. The NSA (in partnership with the UK's GCHQ), collects 'nearly everything a user does on the internet'. Not only do the powerful have unfettered access to our communications, but so do hundreds of thousands of contractors (and anyone who hacks or bribes their way into their systems). And it seems pretty certain that whatever dirty business the US (and UK) are wrapped up in is also going on in China and a bunch of other countries.

One of the worst consequences of the spies' actions is that the companies who have the resources and motivation to protect their customers' privacy (the big software and internet companies — Google, Microsoft, Apple, Facebook, etc.) have been completely compromised. The US spy agencies have forced them to allow access to our data without making their compliance public. (They also do this to smaller companies, as Lavabit case demonstrates.) Every US provider is now an insecure place to store data by definition (and stand to lose around $10 billion yearly as a result).

There's a reason why investigation and surveillance are different words. We need the police to be able to investigate crime, but we cannot allow the state to collect all our private data and allow it to leak all over the place in the usual manner. We are all becoming suspects in a hypothetical crime, and sacrificing our democratic freedoms along the way. Never mind the potential for corruption, blackmail, industrial espionage and the like. And we're not the only technologists who think this way — witness Google's recent announcement of a new peer-to-peer trusted Internet connection system.

What to do?

There are two quite different problems that we might address:

  1. how to prevent powerful agencies like the NSA from compromising our privacy under any circumstances
  2. how to protect most of our data most of the time

These two problems are very different in lots of ways. The brave souls who stand up for human rights in oppressive regimes need the highest levels of privacy and security (i.e. 1.), of course. But many people are not in such difficult circumstances — in which case the much smaller and more tractable goal of reasonably secure privacy (2.) is what we need.

The situation is very similar to the level of security I want for my wallet — I'm not about to wrap it in inch-thick chains and keep it in a fire-proof safe in the basement, but I'm also not going to leave it lying around on the cafe table when I go to the toilet!

This project is about the digital version of that level of security: secure and private communication that is state-of-the-art, using Open Source software, decentralised systems and strong encryption, but which is unintrusive and easy enough for my Mother to use.
